title: 401(k) and IRA Basics: Build a Future You Trust

sections.title: Your Retirement Engine
sections.subtitle: Tax advantages, employer match, and the power of auto-investing

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: How tax-deferred and Roth accounts change your outcome
Why the employer match is the highest-return dollars in personal finance
Which order to fund accounts when money is tight
How to set a target-date or simple index mix and let it run

sections.title: Account Types, Plainly
sections.content: Traditional 401(k)/IRA contributions lower taxable income today; withdrawals are taxed later. Roth 401(k)/IRA contributions are made after tax; qualified withdrawals are tax-free. If your income is lower today than it will be in the future, Roth often shines. If your current tax rate is high, traditional can create breathing room.

points.title: Emergency Buffer First
points.description: Aim for 1–3 months of essentials before aggressive retirement funding.

points.title: Capture the Match
points.description: Contribute at least enough in your 401(k) to get the full employer match. It's a guaranteed return.

points.title: Roth IRA or 401(k)
points.description: Use Roth while in lower tax brackets; switch to traditional as your tax rate rises.

points.title: Max What You Can Automate
points.description: Increase contributions 1%–2% each year or with each raise. Automation beats willpower.

sections.title: Glide With a Target-Date Fund
sections.content: If you don't want to pick funds, a low-cost target-date index fund automatically adjusts stock/bond mix as you approach retirement.

sections.title: Actions for This Month
steps: Log in to your plan and raise contributions by 1% (it’s painless).
If available, enroll in automatic annual increases.
Verify your fund expense ratios are under 0.20%. If not, switch to lower-cost index options.
Set or update beneficiaries for each retirement account.

sections.title: Windfalls With a Purpose
sections.content: Tax refunds and bonuses are easy to spend. Decide now that 50% of any windfall goes to retirement until you hit your target savings rate.
